content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the structure of the game, it seems like a form of the Prisoner's Dilemma. In this game, cooperating (picking R) results in a lower reward for each player individually compared to defecting (picking B), but both players getting the highest reward (45$) happens when they both cooperate.

However, the game is repeated 75 times, which changes the strategy slightly compared to a one-time Prisoner's Dilemma. This setup can be seen as an iterated Prisoner's Dilemma, where players have the opportunity to punish or reward their opponent based on their previous moves.

In this case, if both players consistently cooperate (R), they will each earn 45$ in every round except for the last one when both pick B (12$). But, if one player starts defecting (B) towards the end of the game to maximize their winnings, it could lead the other player to also start defecting. As a result, both players would lose out on potential earnings.

It seems like an optimal strategy would be to cooperate in the beginning rounds and then switch to defecting later on to take advantage of any potential defection from the opponent. However, this approach relies on making assumptions about the other player's behavior, which may not always hold true.

Ultimately, as a human player, it would be difficult to make a definitive choice without knowing more information about the other player's strategy or tendencies. I would likely start by cooperating and then adjust my strategy based on the opponent's moves throughout the game.

In this context, I would choose R {R} for the first round.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

If my opponent chose B in the previous round, I would expect them to continue with that strategy for some time, as they gained a higher payoff by defecting. However, it's worth noting that if I consistently cooperate (R) while my opponent defects (B), they will eventually earn less than if we both switched strategies after some point.

Given this information, it would seem reasonable to switch strategies and choose B for the next round. By doing so, I can punish my opponent's defection from the previous round and potentially encourage them to cooperate in future rounds.
